text: Patient: - or a proven therapy that will slow the progression. So I know that. So thinking in terms of that uh if there was something else that was being done before we actually hit that, that’s almost like saying, “This is my little (laughs) Family Member: Right, right. Patient: You know to hold, you know while I try other things. Of course I have to go relying on your experience. Doctor: Yeah. Right. Uh hum. Patient: And that’s your level of expertise what you’re doing. You’re the oncologist. You know so I’m going to have to weigh… Doctor: Yeah. Sure. Patient: …when we make the decision, we’re going to have to weigh it on what what you’re telling us. Uh so you kind of know where I’m coming from. Doctor: Uh hum. Patient: Um what is where you’re coming from at this point? What is it that you would suggest? What would - Doctor: I think there are like two broad ways to tackle this. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And at this point in time they are mutually exclusive. And in the future the two are probably going to be combined, but right now they are mutually exclusive. One is to give a radio therapy in the absence of hormone therapy. In other words try give you a non-hormonal treatment.

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: I must say that outside of a trial, I haven’t been that excited about the radium, to be honest, in the patients I’ve treated. Family Member: Why? Doctor: Uh, it’s been kind of toxic to the bone marrow. People have kind of gotten beat up when they take it and feeling really tired. Um, and in the trials where it got approved, uh, it didn’t really have big effects on the PSA. It didn’t have big effects on shrink, you know, changing the bone. The only readout was the people who got it seemed to live long. (Sound Door closes) Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So I think, you know, we- Patient: Is that how it works when they give, give the, uh, the seeds in the prostate? Is that, is that similar to that process? Doctor: But we haven’t done the seeds, uh, we just do them alone. But we haven’t, you know, probably somebody’s going to try that concept, which is seeds and some kind of immunotherapy as well. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: There has been, uh, some trials where what they did is they took a patient who has spots in the bone and radiated one spot and give it immunotherapy. There’s some signal that the immunotherapy works better when you do that. Uh, that you’re sort of damaging the cells with radiation and that seems to get your own immune system- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Kind of excited. Patient: Um hum.
conv5077_1-snip21.displayed_text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: I must say that outside of a trial, I haven’t been that excited about the radium, to be honest, in the patients I’ve treated. Doctor: But we haven’t done the seeds, uh, we just do them alone. But we haven’t, you know, probably somebody’s going to try that concept, which is seeds and some kind of immunotherapy as well. There’s some signal that the immunotherapy works better when you do that. Uh, that you’re sort of damaging the cells with radiation and that seems to get your own immune system- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Kind of excited. Patient: Um hum.

text: Patient: If, if, if, if – Doctor: So, if the hormones alone are making those get better, better, better, we give you the trial, I have no way to know did it do anything. So, we usually wait until the hormone stops working by itself. Family Member: And, that’s all just gauged by a PSA or do you do the – Doctor: It’s gauged by PSA as a screening and then, you know, at some point we would then just re-image you, too. Family Member: Hmm. Doctor: But, our experience is, as long as the PSA’s going down, usually the imaging is either getting better or staying stable. So. Patient: If the PSA is that reliable in terms of – Doctor: Ehhh, it’s reliable enough. I don’t know, it’s not unbelievably reliable, but Patient: But, if – Doctor: Rather than, you know, trying to give you a CAT scan every month. Patient: It’s, it’s, it’s unlikely that the PSA is going to go up if things are okay. Doctor: Yes.

Patient: It’s, it’s, it’s unlikely that the PSA is going to go up if things are okay. Doctor: Yes.

text: Family Member: He definitely has it? Doctor: Right. If it's bad enough where you can't button, your shirt or you're constantly dropping things- Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: -or you're burning yourself or you're tripping all the time, that- Patient: My neuropathy is xxx. Doctor: Yeah. Okay. And you know, are you are you falling? Patient: No. Doctor: So those are things where it's like, oh, this is bad, but it's a fine line where it could be bad. So we will obsess about how are you doing? You know, is there any change? So, those are one of the things that we would check, but we give the same attention on the trial as well as off the trial. You know, if you're getting this regular chemo anyways, we'd ask you the same obsessive questions- Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: How are your feet or your hands. You know what your quality of life, are you losing too much weight, you know, is it too rapid of a weight loss? Are you- you know most people are not nauseous and they don’t throw up, but there's always one in a group you know- are you having problems with that or are your bowels, so we would go down the line like that like we do for Xtandi. And of course now that Xtandi's not working, stop the Xtandi because it's just losses you know kind of drive at the moment, but it's something to consider for later, so we do sometimes go back. Family Member: You're saying Xtandi- Doctor: Mhmm. Family Member: -so he would continue to take the Xtandi along with the chemo?

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: We do, speaking of trials, we do have a trial coming up. It’s not open yet. But it’s probably going to be a trial after, uh, uh, actually, let me, let me take a step back. The other trial I didn’t tell you. We do have one other trial, uh, that involves, uh, a combination of two things. Uh, one is called, radium. And radium is a radioactive element that looks like calcium. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And the idea is we can trick the cancer, because prostate cancer is making, stimulating the bone to make new bone. (Sound Door opens) Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we give this radium that looks like calcium, so he gets put in there also, and can give radiation kind of focally. So where there’s spots on the bone, it gives radiation, but it doesn’t radiate the liver or the lung. Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: So that drug, uh, would be another possible option, because it’s a, it’s an approved drug. I tend to use it in men who have more pain. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Have, you know, multiple bone spots. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But, right now, we’re doing a trial where we’re giving that drug in combination with a vaccine. The vaccine is called, sipuleucel-T. And that’s the only vaccine we have for any cancer. Both drugs together have shown that they can improve, uh, how long men live with, from prostate cancer. Patient: Um hum.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
